item.title: Statistics From China Say Coal Consumption Continues to Drop
item.description: The data lends further support to the view that the world’s largest emitter of carbon dioxide may be reaching a peak in coal consumption.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Smoke billowing as men pulled a tricycle in a neighborhood near a coal-fired power plant in Shanxi Province.

item.title: Jailed Afghan Women Are Often Subjected to Virginity Tests, Report Says
item.description: Jailed girls as young as 13 have been forced to undergo invasive and invalid tests, Afghanistan’s human rights commission said.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: Stuart J. Beck, American Who Helped Guide Palau Into Nationhood, Dies at 69
item.description: A lawyer and television executive from Bronxville who helped a remote Pacific island claim a seat in the United Nations General Assembly.
item.dc:creator: SAM ROBERTS
item.media:description: Stuart J. Beck at the United Nations, where he represented Palau, in 2005. Mr. Beck was known as an indefatigable advocate for the Pacific nation’s 21,000 residents.

item.title: Court Hears Suit Against U.N. on Haiti Cholera Outbreak
item.description: A legal battle by Haitian cholera epidemic victims to hold the United Nations accountable reached its highest level in an American court on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Jordan Troops Hunt Militants at Syria Border
item.description: Security officials said several Islamist extremists were killed along with a police officer near the northern city of Irbid.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: U.S. Captures ISIS Operative, Ushering in Tricky Phase
item.description: American defense officials described the capture as a crucial development in battling the Islamic State but said it also raised questions about handling what is likely to be a growing group of detainees.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER, ERIC SCHMITT and MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT
item.media:credit: Kurdistan Regional Security Council, via Associated Press
item.media:description: American and Iraqi special forces working together in an October raid on an Islamic State prison.

item.title: As Air Worsens, New Delhi Turns to Masks. The Flashier the Better.
item.description: Expatriates and health-conscious Indians are leading the way in protecting themselves against the health-threatening atmosphere.
item.dc:creator: GEETA ANAND
item.media:credit: Kuni Takahashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Aurelia Driver, accompanying her children to school in New Delhi, said it was easier to make them wear masks that are “fun and cool.”

item.title: World Briefing: Vote Is Set on North Korea Sanctions
item.description: The United States and China spent seven weeks negotiating the new sanctions, which includes mandatory inspections of cargo ships.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: The Philippines: Gunman Wounds Saudi Preacher and Embassy Worker
item.description: A gunman attacked and wounded a Saudi preacher and a diplomat from Saudi Arabia’s embassy late Tuesday before being killed by a police officer.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Zimbabwe: Ex-Ally Challenges Mugabe
item.description: Joice Mujuru, a former vice president, on Tuesday announced plans to run in elections scheduled for 2018.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Japan: Survey of Working Women Says Sexual Harassment Is Widespread
item.description: A Japanese government study has found that nearly a third of working women who responded to a survey reported being sexually harassed on the job.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Egypt: Autopsy Suggests Italian Student Was Subjected to Lengthy Interrogation
item.description: The findings are the strongest indication yet that the student, Giulio Regeni, was killed by Egyptian security services.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Q. and A.: How North Korea Poses a Threat
item.description: A look at why North Korea has festered as an international crisis for more than a half-century and the international response to that threat.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: North and South Korean soldiers faced off last year across the demilitarized zone in Panmunjom, North Korea.

item.title: Nabil Maleh, Giant of Syrian Cinema, Dies at 79
item.description: Mr. Maleh’s best-known films pushed the envelope in his country, challenging a rigid government and strict social mores.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK
item.media:description: The Syrian film director Nabil Maleh in Damascus in 2007.

item.title: Prosecutors Lay Out Case Against Suspect in Destruction of Mali Shrines
item.description: Prosecutors in The Hague laid out charges in their first case involving Islamic extremism, accusing Ahmad al-Faqi al-Mahdi of destroying shrines in Timbuktu.
item.category: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
item.dc:creator: MARLISE SIMONS

item.title: Italy Moves to Toughen Penalties for Olive Oil Fraud
item.description: The Italian Parliament passed decrees ordering the government to strengthen penalties beyond fines in an effort to bolster the “made in Italy” brand.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Israeli Soldiers Get Lost Using Waze App, and Clashes Follow
item.description: A Palestinian man was killed in a gun battle that ensued after two soldiers who were using Waze, a navigation tool, wandered into a refugee camp in the West Bank.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID
item.media:description: A car burned during an Israeli Army raid the night before in the West Bank refugee camp of Kalandia on Tuesday.

item.title: Osama bin Laden Feared Wife’s Tooth Held a Tracking Device
item.description: Newly released documents suggest that as the United States turned up the pressure, the leader of Al Qaeda grew increasingly concerned about security breaches.
item.category: Office of the Director of National Intelligence
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.media:credit: Warrick Page for The New York Times
item.media:description: The compound where Osama Bin Laden was killed in Abbottabad, Pakistan, in 2011.

item.title: World Briefing: Roadside Bomb in Pakistan Kills 2 Employees of U.S. Consulate
item.description: The employees, both Pakistanis, were in a convoy in the Mohmand tribal region as part of an anti-narcotics team reviewing poppy eradication efforts.
item.dc:creator: IHSANULLAH TIPU MEHSUD

item.title: Russian Foreign Minister Calls for New Chemical Weapons Accord
item.description: Sergey V. Lavrov said the existing treaty was insufficient to address the rising use of those arms by terrorist groups.
item.category: Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.media:description: Foreign Minister Sergey V. Lavrov of Russia, center, at the European headquarters of the United Nations in Geneva on Tuesday.
